ironic/drivers/utils.py.message:
Two things going on here:
1) Swiftclient requires passing in the authtoken and/or service token. It doesn't actually do the magic for us. Our wrapper needs additional work to decompose URLs as it expects everything to be specific container based. As such, this does need more work but I think it is fine for now if the feature is marked experimental.
2) The weakness in in-ability to fallback automatically ultimately means this is not going to work if someone has an intermediate deploy/clean step which fires up the ramdisk. or requires an async call-back.  Definite room for improvement there, but I'm much more comfortable with stressing experimental nature in this case.

This is called four (4) times. Each invocation issues a RESTful API call to the iDRAC Redfish service to obtain information about all of the Ethernet interfaces. That information needs to be fetched only once. Therefore, that should be moved outside of this loop. The data an be massaged to make looking up the NIC ID's MAC easy.

If we move the code out of loop and try to get information once by below api:

/redfish/v1/Systems/System.Embedded.1/EthernetInterfaces/

then it gives response of links instead of mac_address with associated nic as shown below:

{"@odata.context":"/redfish/v1/$metadata#EthernetInterfaceCollection.EthernetInterfaceCollection","@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/Systems/System.Embedded.1/EthernetInterfaces","@odata.type":"#EthernetInterfaceCollection.EthernetInterfaceCollection","Description":"Collection of Ethernet Interfaces for this System","Members":[{"@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/Systems/System.Embedded.1/EthernetInterfaces/NIC.Slot.1-2-1"},{"@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/Systems/System.Embedded.1/EthernetInterfaces/NIC.Slot.1-1-1"},{"@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/Systems/System.Embedded.1/EthernetInterfaces/NIC.Integrated.1-1-1"},{"@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/Systems/System.Embedded.1/EthernetInterfaces/NIC.Integrated.1-2-1"}],"Members@odata.count":4,"Name":"System Ethernet Interface Collection"}

Therefore, I have called api with nic_id 4 times /redfish/v1/Systems/System.Embedded.1/EthernetInterfaces/[NIC_ID]
so that it gives exact mac_address of specific nic_id in response.
We should move querying the MAC addresses outside the look and process them into a dictionary that maps NIC IDs to MACs.  That would turn this code into a dictionary lookup.

This method should be replaced by leveraging sushy's similar functionality [1][2]. As an example, please refer to the 'redfish' inspect interface implementation's use of it [4]. Note that class sushy.resources.system.ethernet_interface.EthernetInterfaceCollection is derived from sushy.resources.base.ResourceCollectionBase. Therefore, its parent class's public methods are available, most notably, get_members().


The following sample code illustrates a prospective approach.


    from oslo_utils import importutils
    ...
    from ironic.drivers.modules.redfish import utils as redfish_utils
    ...
    sushy = importutils.try_import('sushy')
    ...
    class DracRedfishInspect(redfish_inspect.RedfishInspect):

        def inspect_hardware(self, task):
            ...

            super(DracRedfishInspect, self).inspect_hardware(task)


            system = redfish_utils.get(system.task.node)
            ethernet_interfaces = system.ethernet_interfaces.get_members()


            ethernet_interface_identity_to_mac = {i.identity: i.mac_address for i in ethernet_interfaces}

            ...


[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/sushy/src/commit/9d01756833ec97a05f301a4fa1e8b2511d7c5c74/sushy/resources/system/system.py#L297-L310
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/sushy/src/commit/9d01756833ec97a05f301a4fa1e8b2511d7c5c74/sushy/resources/system/ethernet_interface.py
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/commit/7bd643dee69c906738f190bae4391904f8876491/ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/inspect.py#L223-L241

You raise a couple of good points. I asked Chris Dearborn for his recollection of this.

Chris reminded me it was added to ensure this Redfish implementation is consistent with WS-Man's below. WS-Man creates a port object for every NIC port in the system, regardless of its health status; however, the base inspect_hardware() creates one (1) only if the health status of the Ethernet interface is OK.

Also, some versions of the iDRAC firmware may not correctly report the health status.

Therefore, even if more recent versions of iDRAC firmware accurately report the health status, I suggest leaving this logic in. While it could be redundant, it is idempotent and should not require any additional Redfish RESTful API calls. However, it should be executed earlier, before dealing with PXE enabled. The code presently identifies PXE enabled MAC addresses before this block and returns if there are none. That is inconsistent with the WS-Man implementation.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I guess you added this to explain the change in line 40 of the script, but it's actually a fix for cases where a patch becomes a merge patch in zuul tests [1].

some explanation for the script:
* it checks if the pushed patch on a stable/* branch contains 'cherry-picked from' line, which helps to see if a patch is really a backport, as it should on stable branches
* it also checks if the 'cherry-picked from' lines contains hashes that are from patches that have merged, which is useful to see whether a patch is cherry-picked from the latest patch set
* some cases it can happen that a fix (e.g. CI related change) is a 'new' patch, thus not a bug fix backport. In this case the patch has to contain the tag '[stable-only]' in the commit message (e.g. [2]), so that this check script ignores the lack of the 'cherry-picked from' line.

Hope this helps a bit to understand the aim of the check-cherry-picks.sh.

No, my point was that this is now required, so code underneath could have evolved to assume it is not-None, but you're passing None to the API above that requires this argument. Yup, and cleanup will have to be made. My only concern that removing bits from the code also means large refactoring of unit and func tests as they were pretty tangled with checking the RPC versioning.

For this exact reason, I'll stick with providing the only required modifications for bumping the major version and I'll defer cleanups on follow-ups or this change will grow that fat that nobody will have the strenghts and the guts to review it while we're so close from the end of the development cycle.

the problem here is that since we don't mock the compute RPC API, by default the supported version cap is 6.0, so the test would fail if we don't change it.

There are two ways to solve :
- modify the check to say that we only support 6.0 now (that's what I wrote)
- or, somehow mock the RPC API even if we don't cap to 5.2 but rather cap it for 5.13 like it was before this change

The problem here is that this whole testclass is doing a lot of verifications about RPC API support for live migrations. I think we should resolve this by cutting the no longer verifications in a separate patch but I just want to make sure here that we only modify by this change what we need for the RPC API bump and that's it.

I think that modifying the checks to use 6.0 makes the thing that is being tested here irrelevant. This was specifically crafted to make sure we could survive the boundary across which the numa stuff was communicated during live migration. In 6.0, everyone speaks the same version and has the same assumptions, so there's really not as much to poke at here.

IMHO, the thing to do is keep this test as it is until we drop 5.x, but fix it to assume the "we're still pinned at 5.x" environment that this test is intended to validate, and then revisit when we drop 5.x to see if there's anything here that we need to salvage, or if 6.0 makes it totally duplicative of the other tests we have.

Yeah, this was written to validate the questions around "I'm on Rocky, I'm upgrading to Train, what happens when I live migrate NUMA instances from a Rocky compute to a Train compute, or from a Train compute to a Rocky compute?" tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_podman/tas.message: According to the doc, https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/ansible/builtin/package_module.html, it should be present.

This role is also used in upgrade tasks, so we should probably have a var for upgrade/update.

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/podman/podman-baremetal-ansible.yaml#L187-L188
Ah, ok, thanks for the clarification.

One concern I've noticed is that the task to trigger updating all packages is executed in step 3, thus it is executed after step 1. If we need to update podman prior to apply configurations in step 1 then we need to take care of that.

I feel like we should invoke that upgrade tasks about podman at step 4. I don't get why it needs to be executed at step 1...

After digging into a bit now I think we can ignore my above concern.

I understand the current implementation of upgrade_tasks correctly, this step is executed before leapp upgrade which is defined in step 3. Thus this seems to intend to install podman package in centosl7 prior to update, and is not really supposed to be used for upgrade within centos8.
We are supposed to run deploy step tasks later thus we should have the same configuration reapplied. In addition I think updating the package doesn't revert the change already made.

So we should be good with order steps.

We already have tasks to update all packages in update_tasks and upgrade_tasks, so if podman package is already installed then it should be updated by these tasks, even if only install and don't update the package at that task.

Given that this has been released and works using a string, should we support both formats? I tested the following and it worked:

- hosts: localhost
  vars:
    foo: x y z 
    bar:
      - x 
      - y 
      - z 
  tasks:
    - debug:
        msg: "{{ foo if foo is string else bar | join(' ') }}"

        msg: "{{ bar if bar is string else bar | join(' ') }}"

doc/source/2104.rst.message:
Suggested wording:

nova-compute charm: scaling down
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The nova-compute charm has two new actions: ``remove-from-cloud`` and ``register-to-cloud``.

These actions assist with the downscaling of a nova-compute cluster. The ``remove-from-cloud`` action unregisters a Compute service from the cloud and is run prior to unit removal (``juju remove-unit``). This ensures that "dead" services do not linger at the OpenStack level. The ``register-to-cloud`` action allows the operator to revert the process by re-registering the service (providing unit removal has not been made). See the `nova-compute charm`_ README for more information.
.
.
.
_nova compute charm: https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-nova-compute/src/branch/master/README.md#cloud-downscaling

Please file a bug to indicate why this is perceived as an issue. This was done intentionally to prevent the node from being able to boot while the smartnic is receiving it's configuration. That node could be on untrusted networks during that time and thus booting to bios prevents the user workload from loading.

Some sort of further detail is needed.

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

ironic/conductor/utils.py.message: The system is intentionally booted to BIOS as a security mechanism to enable the smartnic enough time to come online, report in, receive it's configuration, and then the deployment can finish. In this case the user requested cannot be booted as the networking still may be in an intermediate state where the provisioning network may still be attached which presents a security risk. It would help to understand why you feel this change is necessary.

There is nothing wrong  when booted to BIOS as a security mechanism in the preparing progress.
But after ironic downloads the user image and set boot to disk，in reboot_and_finish_deploy (agent_base.py) function, before removing provision network，set boot to BIOS will cover boot from disk as set before. So when finished deploy, user image will boot from bios. I feel that is unreasonable.How do you think?
But we need to program the ovs rules for the tenant network. So we need to set to bios program the ovs rules and then boot from disk

I think we should make more consideration on HeadersAuth. For email confirmation, keystoneauth will be skipped if SignedHeaderAuth is passed since the confirmation method require user to click a URL in email content.

Do you think in some circumstance, the confirmation is not a directlly post or put method by users, otherwise a email like confirmation may also need a plugin for HeadersAuth Hook?

Indeed, I think some confirmations will not expose a directly URL to user, for example, the confirmation in some mobile apps. But IMO the email way may not need some more extra information for confirmation process, that don't need the extra headersAuth hook besides the SignedHeaderAuth hook.

So basically, I think we can improve it like this: add a new HeaderAuth to handler the extra specs in request headers, and using entry points to load the handler of extra specs.

Is it possible to standardize the processing by sub-functioning the processing content of 'post_vnf_instantiation' and calling that sub-function from this function as well?

> I don't think the intention of the comment has been conveyed to you, so I will supplement it.

> 
>         self._update_vnfc_resources(vnf_instance, stack_resources,
>                                     vim_connection_info)
>         self._update_vnfc_info(vnf_instance)
> 
>     def post_vnf_instantiation(self, context, vnf_instance, vim_connection_info):
>         self._update_vnfc_resources_and_info(context, vnf_instance, vim_connection_info)
> 
>     def post_change_ext_conn_vnf(self, context, vnf_instance, vim_connection_info):
>         self._update_vnfc_resources_and_info(context, vnf_instance, vim_connection_info)

I created a subfunction that performs common processing, and modified it so that it is called from each of post_vnf_instantiation and post_change_ext_conn_vnf.

> I think so too

These methods already use only common sub-functions,  I think that any further sub-functioning is excessive.

I don't think the intention of the comment has been conveyed to you, so I will supplement it.
By doing the following, you can avoid defining the exact same process in multiple places.
---
    def _update_vnfc_resources_and_info(self, context, vnf_instance, vim_connection_info):

        inst_vnf_info = vnf_instance.instantiated_vnf_info
        access_info = vim_connection_info.access_info

        heatclient = hc.HeatClient(access_info,
            region_name=access_info.get('region'))
        stack_resources = self._get_stack_resources(
            inst_vnf_info.instance_id, heatclient)

        self._update_vnfc_resources(vnf_instance, stack_resources,
                                    vim_connection_info)
        self._update_vnfc_info(vnf_instance)

    def post_vnf_instantiation(self, context, vnf_instance, vim_connection_info):
        self._update_vnfc_resources_and_info(context, vnf_instance, vim_connection_info)

    def post_change_ext_conn_vnf(self, context, vnf_instance, vim_connection_info):
        self._update_vnfc_resources_and_info(context, vnf_instance, vim_connection_info)

src/lib/charm/openstack/magnum/magnum.py.message: Can we have a reference to a bug here inline? So that any colleague would be able to quickly decide in the future if this can be deleted or not.

https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:%22ussuri-fixes%22+(status:open%20OR%20status:merged)

And, sometimes in the future, they are supposed to release an Ussuri Magnum version this changelog 
https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/magnum/ussuri.html.

Due to this amount of changes to fix Magnum Ussuri, we went with the separate PPA to have the charm working. However, I'm not sure when these packages are going to be propagated into cloud archive / default distro repositories (or even if it's tracked anywhere).

ansible/overcloud-ipa-build.yml.message: I found that I needed libgcrypt-devel also.

And by this I mean, if libgcrypt-devel 1.8.3 (CentOS 8.2) happens to be already installed, the code from https://opendev.org/openstack/kayobe/commit/bd5c5c018783028a4748de28d1287f29ef714c8e would leave both libraries at their current version.

Maybe it was required for Bifrost, but in my testing it isn't required for deployment images. Anyway, I believe what may have happened is that you used `state: present`, which wouldn't update libgcrypt when already present. When adding libgcrypt-devel which isn't normally installed, it forces an update of libgcrypt as well.

However, what we really want is libgcrypt 1.8.5, which `state: latest` should provide.
